title: Monday, 18th July, 2016

PM

PM

PM

11:03 am

PM

PM

11:04 am

PM

11:05 am
PM

PM

11:06 am

PM

11:06 am
PM

PM

PM

11:07 am
PM

PM

I'll give you one lot of grey on this and then we can move on

PM

Gyorgy Kovacs from UBS

11:08 am
PM

Mapping the signposts after Friday's coup attempt
The Friday coup attempt In Turkey appears to be over and the government has
regained control. In this note we aim to outline the main signposts that we believe
investors should monitor next with respect to the macroeconomic and market outlook
for Turkey. It is worthwhile briefly re-iterating some of our core views on Turkey prior to
Friday's events. On the macroeconomic front, we projected 4% growth in 2016, with
the view that the external deficit would widen from Q3-16 which would generate
increasing pressures on TRY by into year-end (we projected USD/TRY at 3.10 by end-
2016). We expected a final cut in the O/N lending rate to 8.50% at CBT's July 19
meeting, and then saw rates on hold. We recently highlighted value in long RUB vs TRY
or ZAR as a tactical FX trade, and were O/W Turkish equities within both EMEA and
GEMs as a whole.

PM

Politics: consolidation of power and ramifications for executive presidency
From a political stand-point we see two important areas of uncertainty: a) whether
recent events will generate visible shifts in President Erdogan's and AKP's support vis-à-
vis the military; and b) whether the likelihood of a shift to an executive presidential
system has increased. In addition, we think it will be important to follow how the
government's relationship with the army and various state institutions evolves in the
coming weeks and months. Finally, these events could have implications for the
external relations of Turkey, both in the region and beyond.

PM

Equity Strategy: We stay Overweight in Turkey
Given the drop in the NY-listed Turkish ETF after hours on Friday (4% at one stage),
some weakness in Turkish equity prices should be expected early this week. However,
we retain our Overweight in Turkey within GEMs given that: i) the coup attempt
appears to have failed; ii) the macro fallout from these events is unclear but seems likely
to be limited; and iii) the market continues to trade cheap (

11:09 am
PM

FI/FX Strategy: Friday's weakness likely to reverse, but limited underlying value
USDTRY surged 5% to 3.0157 against the USD late on Friday as political uncertainty
escalated. The subsequent easing of tensions over the weekend may result in most of
these losses being recouped. However we expect any outperformance to soon
dissipate, given sequential current account deterioration, a dovish central bank
backdrop, and waning growth momentum. In rates, Turkish bonds have seen strong
foreign inflows in recent months and the market does not screen as particularly
attractive under our debt scorecard framework.

PM

Macro 1: External account deterioration looks even more likely
In our view the recent developments strengthen our conviction in the expected
deterioration in the external account from Q3 onwards. We previously associated this
with rising oil prices (the trade deficit in June was flat on a 12-month rolling basis) and
a fall in tourism revenues in the summer as we believed that Russia's removal of the
travel ban is unlikely to fully reverse the former. The weekend events seem likely to
have negative repercussions for tourism and thus could result in a faster widening of
the external deficit than currently forecast (to 4.6% of GDP, 12-month rolling by end-
2016).

PM

Macro 2: scope downside to growth, confidence is uncertain
We believe that it is difficult to estimate how these events will affect economic and
consumer confidence and thus impact growth. The key gauges that we would
watch for clarity in this regard are: a) real sector confidence data for July (28 July),
b) PMI (1 August); and c) the stability of FX deposits in the banking system
(currently around USD 207bn). The earlier consumer confidence data on 20 July
are unlikely to include the impact of the events. We think any rapid deterioration in
confidence and/or a jump in FX deposits and sharper than expected TRY weakness
could pose risk to our 4% growth forecast.

11:10 am
PM

Fiscal and monetary policy: room for more stimulus?
Fiscal policy has been prudent in Turkey through political uncertainty in recent
years and strong growth has helped this year's budget performance also (we
predict a 1.4% of GDP deficit in 2016). It is possible that the government will
respond to signs of softer growth with some fiscal boost, having earned fiscal
space. In our view monetary policy has much less room to be eased in the face of
the projected rise in inflation coupled with any TRY weakness as the latter would
hurt the open FX position of the non-financial sector (USD 184bn or 26% of GDP).

PM

Done

Let me find it

PM

03:55 (7 hours ago)

11:17 am
PM

ARM (NTCM BUY): M&A. COULD THIS BE JUST THE BEGINNING.

PM

Steady Neil

PM

We have long advocated the idea that ARM* could be a prime takeover target in the midst of the wave of semiconductor M&A and the strategic importance of their IP in the Internet of Everything (IoE). What we hadn't expected was a 'left field' approach from Internet pioneer Softbank. Yet at 2.30am UK time this morning the FT and the NYTimes report exactly that. Namely, a £23.4 billion deal from Softbank to acquire ARM for £17/share in cash, a 43% premium to its closing price last week.

11:17 am
PM

Softbank is no stranger to deals of course. FT data highlights c.US$82bn spent on 140 deals over the past decade. These include investments in Alibaba, eAccess, Sprint Nextel, Supercell and Didi Chuxing.

PM

While tempting, as it must be, to lock in gains on any share price appreciation in ARM as a result of this news we continue to advocate buying ARM shares. Why? Because the strategic importance of the Arm technology and model in our view is one which may attract additional suitors. It is not merely a deal reflective of sterling weakness in our view. Sure, ARM could be considered an attractive target given the c.15% fall in Sterling against the dollar and c.30% fall against the Japanese Yen over the last year (Bloomberg data). But the real attraction in our view, to a range of potential suitors, is their core technology. ARM has what we view as an unassailable library of IP processor designs based on chip performance, size and power performance across all IoE (Internet of Everything) applications. ARM is growing at 10x the rate of the semiconductor industry it serves and is increasingly the glue that binds the disruptive forces of the entire digital world, not just $700 smartphones.

PM

"Buy more ARM" ??

11:18 am
PM

It's up 43 per cent

ARM Holdings PLC (ARM:LSE): Last: 1,692, up 503 (+42.30%), High: 1,752, Low: 1,691, Volume: 16.26m
PM

But let's hear Campling out

11:19 am
PM

We have seen many M&A deals in the semiconductor field. Avago buying Broadcom, NXP buying Freescale, Qualcomm bought CSR and Intel purchased Altera, to name just four high profile deals. Why? The over-arching premise for us is that this wave is being driven by the disruptive nature of IoT. System on Chip (SoC) and the integration of semiconductor expertise (from Microcontrollers, to RF and sensors) is designed to increase functionality, speed time to market, offer one stop silicon solutions and increase potential silicon content per design win. In other words, technology cycles are far quicker to play out, scale is increasingly important, barriers at leading edge geometries are increasing and the cost of technology improvements are increasingly expensive.

PM

But while most deals appear, in our view, to have focused on efficiency gains or scale positioning to date it has long begged the most obvious question… Why doesn't a company buy THE DISRUPTOR?

PM

ARM is the disruptor in our view. With its dominance in mobile processors at the foundation, all things connected should drive significant growth in its total addressable market – ARM has legs for years. We had argued that strategic buyers could step in – the Chinese, as they continue to move up the value chain (although admittedly there could be regulatory hurdles to thwart such ambitions), or potentially cash rich Qualcomm or prime competitor Intel who we have argued is the victim of ARM's ability to 'out Intel, Intel'.

11:19 am
PM

We also remind ourselves of the words of VC guru Marc Andreessen last month in discussion on technology M&A when he foretold "more M&A happening in the pipeline – meaning companies in consideration or negotiation — than in the last four years." (Bloomberg conference). The reason being that both company valuations down from their peaks last year, and companies that "now have to go shopping to fill in gaps in their portfolio," Andreessen said to expect a "run of M&A the rest of this year and next year." At the time we highlighted ARM in the UK as a likely target. We just hadn't expected the first arrow to have been fired from Minatu-Ku in Japan.

undefined

Chad John mentioned to poor Liberum chaps

11:22 am
PM

Sebastian Jory and colleagues would like to recall the message, "FTSE 100 Red Flags
Seven Sinners – 2016 Edition"

PM

We present the third edition of our annual ‘sinners’ note,
scoring FTSE 100 companies based on thirteen areas that
may indicate business risk – the Red Flags. We begin with a
qualitative assessment from company auditors followed by
eleven quant screens and finish with an evaluation of
remuneration policies. We again find that seven companies
screen with 4 flags or more, with Pearson and BAE making
their second consecutive appearance. Of the five new
entrants, ARM, Smith & Nephew and Next score worst.
We highlight that both the 2014 and 2015 lists
underperformed in the year following publication.

PM

ARM Holdings (SELL, TP 650p), 5 flags
• Consistent user of exceptionals, particularly vis-a-vis yearly share-based
payments to staff. The auditors also flag that management assumptions
around compensation remain subjective
• We flag deferred revenue believing ARM is using licensing backlogs to
offset royalty volatility

11:23 am
PM

Bar the broken ARM advice, this looks a decent tome

PM

Which may well find its way to the usual place

PM

Liberum came out with it's hands up later in the morning

11:24 am
PM

We upgrade ARM to a Hold recommendation with a 1700p price target following its agreement to be acquired by Softbank and change of analyst coverage. We did not expect ARM to be acquired, least of all by Softbank. However, the independence that Softbank can continue to bring to ARM can make the deal more acceptable to its customers in our opinion. This is likely to reduce the chances of a counter-bid, particularly if Softbank can assure key stakeholders like Apple, Qualcomm and TSMC that the strategy will remain unchanged and that investments in the technology will be increased. We believe a key area of increased investments by Softbank will be the Internet of Things.

PM

We confess that we did not expect ARM to be acquired at all because we believe that its value lies in its independence which would be lost in an acquisition. However, we did not factor in the possibility of a company with very peripheral connection to ARM's industry and operations such as Softbank becoming the acquirer. To that extent the acquisition by Softbank retains ARM's independence and is unlikely to trigger significant objections from key customers like Apple and Qualcomm.

PM

On the other hand the continued competitiveness of ARM's microprocessor technology is vital to many companies including TSMC, Apple, Qualcomm and Samsung. They will need reassurance that Softbank is truly committed to investing in ARM in all areas of its operations including smartphones, networking, servers, microcontrollers and the internet of things. While such commitments are usually provided at the time of an acquisition, priorities may change in the longer term.

11:25 am
PM

We believe ARM's board is recommending the acquisition because it believes that the company will need to increase its investments significantly in order to remain competitive and in a leadership position in multiple technology silos. The increase in investments amidst a slowdown in end-demand may not be possible as a listed entity, without significantly affecting its share price and shareholder returns.

One of Softbank's key areas of increased investment is likely to be the internet of things. As a major player in the global telecommunications and internet industries, the company clearly sees the long term revenue potential in the internet of things. The acquisition of ARM is expected to be a key component in exploiting that potential to its maximum advantage.

PM

While we don't rule out a competitive bid, we believe the chances of it happening are low. A counter-bid by Intel would trigger anti-trust concerns, while those by Apple, Qualcomm or Samsung could lead to a reduction in revenues and cash flows due to a loss of independence. The price to be paid is too high even for some of these big companies in our opinion, given this potentially negative outcome. That money (£24bn+) would be better used to try and develop an alternative processor technology if the acquisition is such a serious cause for discomfort.

We, therefore, upgrade the stock to a Hold from a Sell, raising our price target to 1700p (from 650p). Our price target equals the acquisition price by Softbank. The change of recommendation also coincides with a change of analyst coverage.

PM

PM

Gauging the impact of Brexit on both London property markets

PM

This is 50 pages from an extended SocGen team

11:32 am
PM

The British exit from the EU has struck fear into the UK real estate market at
a time when the property upswing cycle looked set to reverse anyway on
growing supply and high prices. The past two cycles and our forecasts
suggest that commercial property prices could fall 25% peak-to-trough on a
rent decline alone. But investors are also now rushing to sell their liquid
positions in UK REITs and CRE property funds, and five have now
suspended redemptions. If all this adds to the general market concern on
CRE pricing levels, property prices could fall further on an additional leg of
yield expansion (see table on page 3), as they did in the last two crises.

PM

But residential might be more an issue While in recent stress tests the major UK banks
were assessed with declines of around 30% in commercial real estate prices, we fear that
London residential could experience an even more severe downturn. Brexit will damage the
UK economy, and some companies will almost certainly have to relocate parts of their
business to retain access to the EU single market.

PM

Shock to the economy PwC estimates this leading to between 70k and 100k fewer jobs in
the UK financial services sector by 2020, and 950k overall across the UK. On the basis of
50k job losses in London (only in line with previous cycles), office rental values could come
down by 24% (link) on our computation. Meanwhile residential should also be in trouble,
especially given the now historically high London prices (averaging 12x London earnings),
twice the long-term average, while we could see ‘forced sellers’ from relocations.

11:33 am
PM

CRE prices down 25% However, this time around the commercial real estate cycle might
be less severe thanks to lower leverage, low yields, contained oversupply and prices already
8-11% cheaper in euros and dollars. Overall on our rental forecasts, UK REIT capital values
should fall ~25% - which implies a further 21% off share prices from here.

PM

Sheesh

PM

Flight-to-quality We expect wider polarisation between prime and non-prime properties,
and principally in retail. However if London’s property market invulnerability and ‘safe haven’
status (link) is challenged, CRE prices could fall further, by 32% on a 50bp yield expansion,
from a 4.0% equivalent yield to 4.5% (from 2.8% to 4.4% net initial yields).

11:34 am
PM

Uncertainties The first uncertainty is the framework and timing of the UK exit. The second
is the impact on the economy, and how badly it could hit London housing prices. Any
positive newsflow might see a short relief rally ahead of a declining rental cycle, poor
economic data points and consensus downgrades. However, we do expect the recent
rebound in real estate stocks may ultimately turn out to be just a ‘dead cat bounce’ (Link).

PM

As i say, there's 50 pages here -- so look out for it in the usual place

11:46 am
PM

160p-200p

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 183.45, down 2.5 (-1.34%), High: 184.80, Low: 177.05, Volume: 18.05m
PM

We downgrade the shares from OUTPERFROM to NEUTRAL and
increase our Target Price from £1.6 to £2. GLEN has rallied strongly YTD
and while it isn’t quite mission accomplished on deleveraging, credit
concerns have reduced materially and an ongoing commitment from the
company to reduce net debt to ~$15bn should secure the group's investment
grade credit rating. However, we remain negative on copper, GLEN's largest
exposure at ~40% of industrial EBITDA, due to subdued demand and healthy
mine supply growth, and we believe this will cap upside from here.

11:47 am
PM

Investment case: Navigation of the market's debt concerns was a key part
of our bull base at the start of the year (GLEN.L: Glencore - Trading out of
the trough). Valuation has now re-rated back to our target multiples (6x
industrial EV/EBITDA) and is now more aligned with peers. Successful
delivery of the company's main earnings and debt reduction targets together
with latent capacity growth in copper and zinc still provides upside potential
on a medium term view, but weak copper prices may result in a slower than
planned return of copper volumes. Thermal coal is a potential wild card
and prices have rallied recently following production curtailments in China,
but we do not assume further upside from here.

PM

Catalysts: Divestments (a further $2-3bn possible in H216), H1 earnings on
24 August, copper and thermal coal prices.
■ Valuation: We raise our TP from £1.60 to £2 reflecting a 10% reduction in
our GBP/USD assumption and a 4% increase to 2017 EBITDA largely on
higher coal price realizations. We preview H116 earnings in this note; while
we see the company on track for full year guidance we expect H1 annualised
marketing EBIT to fall below 2016 guidance of $2.4-2.7bn with Q116 results
from marketing peers pointing to softer trading conditions.

PM

Actually, CS have a broader sector note out

11:48 am
PM

Ahead of results season

PM

The mining sector has rebounded strongly this year. Credit
concerns have diminished and prices have rallied, particularly steel inputs.
Post Brexit we raise target prices by ~10% to reflect a weaker GBP, but
most share prices are now close to our target prices and the sector is no
longer cheap against the underlying commodities. Earnings risk is positive,
but looking out to 2017 we continue to see supply headwinds in the two
most important earnings drivers - iron ore and copper

PM

Results season – what to expect: We publish our forecasts and outlooks
for company results in this note. We expect more optimistic outlook
statements with more focus on medium-term growth options, but this will be
an important balancing act; M&A or capex increases are likely to still be
taken negatively. Watch points: 1) Upside risk to capex: capex is down
~70% from the 2012 peak and our analysis suggests that over the medium
term it could rise by over 30% vs 2016 guidance; 2) Unit costs troughed in
H116 and rising FX and inputs could present upside risk to guidance for
H216; 3) Iron ore guidance was downgraded by RIO and BHP earlier this
year. We do not expect material further downgrades but outlook statements
from RIO, BHP and Vale will be closely watched.

11:48 am
PM

Stocks: Our preferred names are BHP, BOL, Aurubis and Acacia. We
continue to like the outlook for zinc, gold and copper TCRCs.

Matchtech Group plc ("Matchtech" or the "Group" or "the Company" ), the specialist Engineering and Technology (IT & Telecoms) recruitment agency, announces that, subject to shareholder approval, the Company intends to rename as Gattaca plc.

The name change is the next step in the Group's development, following the acquisition of Networkers International plc in April 2015. The acquisition brought Telecoms and Technology expertise to Matchtech's existing strength in Engineering and Technology. It has enabled the Group to capitalise on the convergence of the skill sets demanded by these markets and allowed Matchtech to internationalise its existing service offering by leveraging Networkers' existing global infrastructure.

12:01 pm
PM

Gattaca is a 1997 American science fiction film written and directed by Andrew Niccol. It stars Ethan Hawke and Uma Thurman, with Jude Law, Loren Dean, Ernest Borgnine, Gore Vidal, and Alan Arkin appearing in supporting roles.[2] The film presents a biopunk vision of a future society driven by eugenics where potential children are conceived through genetic manipulation to ensure they possess the best hereditary traits of their parents
